message.content:
We first need to extract only those transactions that affect the fixed assets balance. In our “example‐style” method the net fixed assets at period end equals the beginning (initial) fixed assets plus any fixed asset purchases (additions) minus any depreciation expense made on fixed assets.

Step 1. Identify the starting (initial) fixed assets:
• Look at the “Initial20231231001” row with type “Fixed Assets”. Its amount is 8,000,000.0.
  Initial Fixed Assets = 8,000,000.00

Step 2. Find “Fixed Assets Purchase” transactions:
• In this data the “FixedAsset20231231001” row (type “Fixed Assets Purchase”) shows an acquisition of fixed assets for 886,161.25.
  Fixed Asset Additions = 886,161.25

Step 3. Sum Depreciation expense entries (which reduce the asset’s book value):
• One depreciation transaction on 2024‑01‑01 (“Depreciation20240101001”) with amount = 45,745.88 
• A later depreciation on 2024‑02‑01 (“Depreciation20240201002”) with amount = 60,147.44 
  Total Depreciation = 45,745.88 + 60,147.44 = 105,893.32

Step 4. Calculate the final (end period) fixed assets value:
  Final = Initial + Additions – Depreciation
    = 8,000,000.00 + 886,161.25 – 105,893.32 
    = 8,886,161.25 – 105,893.32 
    ≈ 8,780,267.93

Thus, the answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "8780267.93"
  }
}
